text: @tommytomtj The slide into authoritarianism seems to start in many cases with the assumption that the enemy is *so* evil and *so* dangerous that normal standards and processes can and must be suspended in their case. But the "enemy" group, in time, becomes infinitely flexible.

@tommytomtj I think a good place to start is a very critical dissection of one's own relationship to the enemy, e.g. whether your policies, preferences & philosophy stand on their own two feet with or without a Terrible Evil to fight.

The tricky thing about authoritarianism is that from the inside it looks much like anti-authoritarianism, in much the same way that the most fervent religious zealots are the ones who care most about denouncing *other* gods

text: If you can't comprehend why the working poor are often more skeptical about/frustrated by welfare "cheaters" than even the rich, the way to resolve your confusion is to try paying your rent by waitressing at a Waffle House full-time for 6 months

It's a massive % of the workforce, and they don't show up at your donor dinners or subscribe to your overpriced news rags so unless you've limped a mile in their shoes it's unsurprising that you don't care about them except insofar as they're a useful cudgel against other elites
If you've never spent an extended period working a job after which your feet hurt so badly you had to be careful peeling your socks off, I'm not sure you should be a politician or journalist

Do you recall the difference between developing an intense interest in one subject and just "cramming" for another? These are qualitatively different experiences that lead to dramatic differences in retention and accessibility later in life

This is actually how all learning occurs for both adults and children. There are strategies for forcing statements of fact and basic procedures into memory for recall, but subsequent untaught insight requires models that develop via confusion/curiosity + exploration of answers

Quick recap: kids are curious; they direct their attention to what interests them and develop models to explain what they see, what happens when they act. They become confused when new information is incompatible with those models. They're driven to explore to achieve coherence.

urls.title: Prefer comedy over tragedy
urls.description: Last week my mom died after a three year battle with cancer. I was fortunate to be by her bedside in the last few days of her life. At the beginning she was lucid and we got to say good bye— a great privilege. Then, for days, I watched her struggle for every breath as her breathing got shallower and shallower, until it eventually stopped.

text: In particular, I VERY strongly recommend this piece about his experience spending time with his mom in her final days, and what he gleaned from that: https://t.co/w0sZJYqWS2 https://t.co/A2fCd0yNFf

I *really* enjoy @spakhm in large part because I strongly agree or strongly disagree with just about everything he says. He's smart enough to have exchanged considerable upside in order to not be a coward, and that counts for a lot. Check out his Substack: https://t.co/VrYsuV7nMI
@CharlieSand3rs @UnfleshedO What are your thoughts on the replication crisis in the social sciences?

There's plenty of published work that is, methodologically, trash. It's still not the case that you can effectively filter by assuming that whatever speaks to the norms of the day is "the good stuff," nor that destroying any record of the "bad" work aids the aim of truth-seeking.

@petpierce @jkmilton @curiousmind44 I'm certainly not suggesting that working in film under these conditions is particularly dangerous. But neither is having a bite outdoors with someone you live with.

@petpierce @jkmilton @curiousmind44 Yes, the advice is for people to dine with people in their households at the table. Some people are still seeing their friends, which they will do whether or not you destroy the entire city's restaurant industry.
@petpierce @jkmilton @curiousmind44 Hey Jim, if you're going to block me, would you mind not constantly showing up in my replies? It's just sad.

@petpierce @jkmilton @curiousmind44 My issue is that eating outdoors, spaced, appears to be quite safe. It's *very* unclear whether presymptomatic testing provides an additional layer of safety that renders one setup considerably preferable to the other.
@petpierce @jkmilton @curiousmind44 I'm not claiming there's a double standard.

@petpierce @jkmilton @curiousmind44 The issue I'm addressing here is specifically whether this testing protocol works on presymptomatic samples. And I'm not able to find any data for that. That's all.
@jkmilton @petpierce @curiousmind44 Bye, Jim. I don't need anyone who thinks I'm "monetizing drama" anywhere near me. Deepest apologies if my ability to feed myself presents an issue for you.

@petpierce @jkmilton @curiousmind44 How is that not an issue? You're testing people *before* they've developed symptoms. A test that is nearly 100% accurate on samples from patients *with symptoms* is great for clinical applications, but that data is way less helpful for screening presymptomatic workers.

@petpierce @jkmilton @curiousmind44 This test had superb accuracy on samples derived from patients "with a suspected respiratory infection," meaning that they were symptomatic (pg. 32). Which makes it an incredibly useful test! But AFAICT, there's no public data for presymptomatic samples. https://t.co/XukrKNvR5h

@petpierce @jkmilton @curiousmind44 The issue remains whether these tests, including PCR tests, can consistently detect infections *prior to the onset of symptoms.* I tried to find data relevant to this question on this test, and could not.

@natesayer To me, you sound *exactly* like the people you're so obsessed with fighting, dressed in an entirely different class aesthetic and different team colors. Nobody has the barest hint of skepticism for anything but the enemy, and I'm absolutely sick of it.

@natesayer "Sowing distrust" and "suppressing turnout" are miles apart. Not even the same ballgame. If you trust *anything* about the current process without a dramatically greater degree of transparency about the decisions being made than is currently offered, I'm not listening to you.
@simoj_ For my part, I'm seeing "this IS fraud" and "there is NO substantial fraud" to great divergent effect in my own feed. My question is "isn't this what formal investigations are for?"
@recursus Do we literally just never have investigations, because the (rather opaque) system *must* work? Genuinely asking. What's the trigger for an investigation? I feel like a broken record, here.

@recursus I posted one thread. I can give you another that specifically asserts this, if you'd like. Admittedly, I don't know much about poll watchers, and have had a hard time figuring out to what extent they'd be able to prevent various types of fraud, because... I'm not an investigator.
@simoj_ Do you think my reasoning is motivated?
@recursus Again, how inconsistent would any given batch need to be to trigger an investigation? If the answer is "nothing ought to trigger any investigation," I'm done.
@recursus Why would you expect any one batch of mail-in votes from across the state to differ substantially from those already tallied and those soon to be tallied?
@recursus Specifically, if a later batch of mail-ins differs substantially from earlier mail-ins, at what point is an investigation triggered? If the answer is "never," my hackles raise.

@recursus It doesn't easily explain why D votes would spike after the shift from in-person to mail-in vote counting had already occurred, and had a steady but stable D-leaning trajectory. That's the question on the table.

@recursus Again, the point of an investigation isn't to prove impropriety by any means necessary, it's to determine whether it occurred. Are we supposed to just shrug and keep the door open for someone to randomly admit felony involvement, apropos of nothing?
@recursus I'm asking you how anyone is meant to assert that the strength of that shift was "too strong," barring any investigation.

@recursus I don't think anyone is questioning the theory that mail-in ballots would skew D; they're questioning the extent to which they did, after a great number of mail-in ballots had already been tallied, somewhat proportionately to where additional voted were needed to shift outcomes.
@recursus I did read what you wrote, and I'm asking you a very specific and highly relevant question about it.
@recursus What sort of "mechanism" do you expect anyone to find, barring the kind of access an investigation would be granted?
@recursus How many investigations of financial impropriety are based initially on vague suspicions and unexplained cash transfers? That's the fucking job.

@recursus It doesn't seem to me like you necessarily need one, because that's in fact what an investigation should be attempting to uncover? That's what the investigation of *every other* alleged crime endeavors to uncover?

text: @BretWeinstein @SamHarrisOrg I don't think @SamHarrisOrg meant to call my impartiality into question, but this is part of the problem with the conversation. It's assumed broadly that advocating for investigation is equivalent to advocating against the standing results. It's very hard to work around that!

@SamHarrisOrg Yes. If something looks terribly awry, it shouldn't matter if it would change the overall result *and* it shouldn't matter if the fraud favored the loser. You don't just investigate fraud to validate the current election, you do it to prevent future fraud!

@non___linear Yes. It's extremely frustrating to me, in large part because it reduces neutral parties to whispers and experts to anonymity-by-necessity if they want to avoid catching partisan ire from one "side" or the other, potentially for life.

This is an example of a thread where I read through it as a layman and think, "yeah, this should be addressed." A zillion people looking for reasons to confirm or disconfirm it while calling one another stupid is not addressing it. https://t.co/08GX9CopfJ

Lots of folks are asking where I find the results improbable, and the answer is: I don't. I'm not a data analyst and I don't want to become one for this. I'm just watching the very idea of voter fraud investigations become politicized in a way that's deeply unsettling to me.

text: I say "the people closest to you" because these are the people you know. You have evidence about whether they're kind and thoughtful. You don't have to adopt a belief about the universal goodness of humanity, you just have to trust your own judgment and not delegate it away.

If there is any single belief that can act as a strong antibody to cult indoctrination, it's probably the belief that the people closest to you can be good — morally sound, wise and deeply loving — even if they fundamentally disagree with you about how the world works.

The people who wind up most harmed by cults tend to be (1) the people whose commitments cause them to be complicit in perpetuating the harm, and (2) partners and children who must remain in good standing with the leadership in order to maintain their most important relationships

People choose for themselves whether or not they will tie their own identity, sense of purpose and economic/romantic opportunities into an all-consuming hierarchy. It doesn't make sense to try to "force" any free individual into that; it makes sense to capture it when it arises.

One thing I want to highlight is that they *do* tend to give people some degree of self-empowerment, and they generally do let people self-select into high-commitment and potentially more manipulative roles. It's not the "brainwashing" a lot of people have come to expect.

I don't think people really understand how many little groups like this exist or their mechanisms for growth. The leaders who are successful tend to target the moneyed-but-meaningless, B/C-list celebrities and "social butterfly" nodes in well-connected networks

Most of the groups I was involved in were very small and to this day have no real name recognition outside of very niche Californian techie/burner circles. They varied widely wrt the degree to which I felt they were harmless (sometimes even beneficial) or actively manipulative

To be clear, I never got super deep into any particular cult or cult-like org. At one point I began training to become a sort of psychological mapping coach for one lesser-known group, but I dropped off in the second week.
@GwynneThomson I was in a long-term relationship with someone who was really getting into it

IMO, 2020 is the year that the *political* cult really metastasized as an organizing force in American life, though it was developing for years prior. All the same elements: gurufication of leadership, separation of friends and families, doctrine above discussion

I don't think this requires brilliant master-planning; it crops up organically amongst people who are living in a perpetual state of low-level panic and uncertainty, who lack achievable cultural milestones and are beholden to norms that make them feel bad about what they want

The problem is that people experiencing novel insights and breakthroughs are very vulnerable to becoming hooked on that fix, associating it with a single person or small hierarchy, and becoming rapidly uninterested in finding meaning or purpose elsewhere

A lot of the same themes and ideas recur in successful spiritual and philosophical cults, because they're generally useful concepts and they speak to confusing and aversive desires that a lot of people feel unable to explore on their own. That's not the problem

@jasonintrator @GwynneThomson @postpostpostr You were claiming that opposition to "associations with Mao" is "often" actually intended to delegitimize racial justice movements. That's an extraordinary claim and a very heated smear, and you provided no evidence for it. It was shameful.

@jasonintrator @GwynneThomson @postpostpostr I have no problem with that argument. There's no question that Americans' familiarity with Hitler's atrocities makes it much easier to assume malicious intent when someone dabbles with his symbols. But the reply I quoted above wasn't about that, and it was deeply irresponsible.

@jasonintrator @GwynneThomson @postpostpostr I'll have to take your word for it. I don't think I know a single person who owns any clothing with a Mao print, and if I come across such a person I'd appreciate the invitation to talk to them about it without entertaining vague accusations of racist ulterior motives.

@jasonintrator @GwynneThomson @postpostpostr If Mao kitsch is ubiquitous at Yale, I sincerely think the entire faculty has a responsibility to adjust the curriculum a bit to ensure the student body understands what that imagery represents.

@jasonintrator @GwynneThomson @postpostpostr I can't say I think Mao kitsch is "ubiquitous," but insofar as it is I think it's perfectly reasonable and probably somewhat morally obligatory to ask why anyone is comfortable with that.
@jasonintrator @GwynneThomson @postpostpostr Can you really not think of a more obvious reason someone might take an issue with an American politician wearing Mao kitsch while campaigning?

@jasonintrator @GwynneThomson @postpostpostr Do you have any evidence whatsoever that anyone "attacking associations with Mao" today is doing that because of anything remotely related to the Black Panthers, rather than because he was one of the most vicious genocidal authoritarians of all time?

@AffablePsycho @default_friend @naval Truthfully, all of these things can be dealbreakers after any amount of time. Familiarity without baseline value alignment breeds contempt. Nobody wants to have to choose between acting in accordance with what they value most and betraying that to avoid having their life explode.

@AffablePsycho @default_friend @naval Arguably the fact that it's become the norm to mess around with each other for months or years without entertaining the sort of commitments that suss these things out is part of the reason millennials struggle to commit at all
@geostan77 @Austen https://t.co/1OTChqT57h
@spakhm @antoniogm Nobody is as far from doing their time as "guy in the van" as they'd like to think, but some people can never be kept there for too terribly long.

@default_friend @naval e.g. What do you do if one of your parents becomes critically ill? What do you do if your kid isn't thriving at his or her school? If one of you comes to hate a secure and/or lucrative job, do you agree on whether to stay and suffer or cut back and go exploring?

@default_friend To my mind it generally applies to early filters, the basic resume stuff you care about most when you've not actually gotten to know someone. @naval & I chatted about "dealbreakers" on CH once, and he pointed out that alignment on the genuinely critical life stuff is what counts.

text: @paulomesteves San Francisco is *really* struggling with meth use, and there unfortunately aren't any great pharmocological treatment options https://t.co/WkY9ynqDet https://t.co/aZmuxo4mVS

@paulomesteves It absolutely makes sense to me that Portugal could very effectively reduce heroin use just by tackling trafficking and diverting users to free treatment focused on substitution (methadone and suboxone). My big question is whether that model still works without substitution.

Could it work for the US opioid crisis? I think so, if Americans were open to the idea of imposing sanctions on individuals without criminal proceedings. But barring that, just dramatically increasing the availability of suboxone treatment would be a *fantastic* idea.

Because treatment relies heavily on a pharmocological approach and very few of the country's drug users use stimulants, it's hard to say whether the same strategies would work for the US's meth problem. There is no "suboxone for meth." Treatment is much trickier.

I think there's a lot to like about Portugal's strategy, but IMO it's fair to hypothesize that it works well in part because the Portuguese just don't use a lot of drugs aside from cannabis, and traffickers are aggressively targeted and prosecuted.

Portugal's drug situation is also mostly about... cannabis, which is still illegal to grow or sell.

Most people enter treatment in Portugal for either cannabis or heroin, the latter being very well managed with medication.

There is almost no meth use in Portugal. https://t.co/dtFCWGTf31
One thing Portugal seems to do very well is making pharmacological drug treatment (e.g. methadone, suboxone) extremely accessible, which is almost certainly a very good idea

Portugal keeps coming up whenever I discuss drug policy, so please note:

— Portugal prosecutes and imprisons drug dealers & traffickers

— Drug use is not legal & Portugal can impose a variety of sanctions for possession of small quantities https://t.co/kp8Z2Y5hj9

@BillWal35159851 To be clear, the only thing I've proposed — jailing *dealers* — is absolutely in line with Portugal's strategy. Portugal doesn't jail users, though it *can* confiscate their property, restrict their travel, cut off their personal contacts and restrict their job opportunities.

text: This is a guy who really thought he could play the system. He was doing things like sending rape threats against one victim to different victims, believing he could bypass extant restraining orders this way. Maybe if he'd faced real consequences earlier, he'd have thought twice.

I can't know for sure whether getting away with it for so long emboldened him to keep doing what he was doing and to target more women, but in this case that was the result. Treatment won't work for someone who isn't willing to genuinely submit themselves to it.

I consider myself one of his most fortunate victims, because most of the women he threatened to rape, torture and murder had to get on with life *for years* knowing that he was out on the street in their city. This is the first time he's had to face serious criminal consequences.

So many people are ignorant of the *many* programs already embedded in the criminal justice system. My understanding is that my own stalker evaded prior charges via CA's pretrial mental health diversion program, and did not fully fulfill his court-ordered treatment obligations. https://t.co/P3DZe0IU4r

@_ReallyNotReal I agree 100% that "ACAB" generally comes from a very privileged place. Of course most people would prefer to never need the cops! But when you need them, you really NEED them. You can go truly crazy trying to figure out how to protect yourself on your own.

@_ReallyNotReal Thank you for sharing. I had a lot of support, even had the opportunity to get advice from experienced personal protection professionals. But my takeaway was that civilians don't have a lot of options if someone wants to hurt them, especially if they can't leave home to just hide

One final thing: going to the police protected me, but it also gave me the opportunity to provide evidence critical to some counts concerning other victims. My stalker is going to trial on 11 total charges. Only two of them concern me.

text: In order to get the civil restraining order, I needed someone to serve my stalker with notice. The same SFPD sergeant who handled my criminal case freely offered to do this for me. He returned my calls. He encouraged me to call if I ever felt I was in danger.

I did eventually obtain a civil restraining order — after several months and three court appearances. But because I had filed a police report early, I was *also* much more quickly given a criminal protective order — with stronger protections and no hassle on my end.

While the focus of the other shows in the `Law & Order' franchise largely deal with murder cases, the SVU detectives frequently deal with crimes, such as rapes, in which the victim survives and assists authorities in the investigation. @profswarn @VaelinVanGogh @TheRealJohulka @SarahTheHaider Yet the rate of technological progress has accelerated alongside population growth, as I'd predict, and I'd predict it to slow with a decline in population for the same reasons. @profswarn @VaelinVanGogh @TheRealJohulka @SarahTheHaider It's relatively small groups of people that end up generating massive global increases to productivity and quality of life, and thusfar we've had to cultivate a lot of other people and their ideas to make those gains, because failure is the default.

@profswarn @VaelinVanGogh @TheRealJohulka @SarahTheHaider If finite resources were the bottleneck, you would not see fewer people living in abject poverty after going from 1 billion to 7 billion. @profswarn @VaelinVanGogh @TheRealJohulka @SarahTheHaider The carrying capacity of the earth is contingent on the development and spread of technology. @Marco_OrneMend Why should they have to do anything? A lot of people are born into industry towns that burn out when the global market shifts. It's not nice, it's not fair, it's just the reality.
@cybersygh Just remember that *you're* the one interviewing those lucky mofos

This means helping people:
- build real marketable skills
- own specific assets that are prerequisites for participating in the skilled economy
- move around so that they can capture the best opportunities for someone with the skills that they have

I get the horror at the initial realization that life is this hard for *anybody,* but elites need to understand that their role is helping create viable, sustainable and irrevocable paths *out,* not pumping out gameable patches that rarely help anybody achieve escape velocity

These are not the same sorts of people. Lives lived in poverty are as diverse as any other sweeping slice of the demography. The people looking down from more privileged perches fail to see these distinctions more often than not, and rail against the idea that they *should.*

There are also a lot of people — if you live in these towns, you WILL meet them — who take advantage wherever they can and actively claw the precocious crabs right back down into the bucket. Their own children included. Their lives are miserable, for sure, but not for no reason.

Outside of the private feeder school and "modest" trust fund bubbles are a lot of people willing to work very hard for a very long time as long as they can expect to not be interfered with, and that their gains won't be taken from them arbitrarily.

My main issue is with coastal elites that can't tolerate the idea that life is actually very hard for the nowhere-town "deplorables" they've never met, so they vascillate between proposing "let them eat cake" policies & viciously attacking them for a lack of gratitude & "values"

text:
@twicrates Let the drunk flow through you, wisdom from the vine

Or whatever fuck

@default_friend @radicalgusto People seem to offhandedly dismiss this as "lust" and degrade it, but I think most people have experienced this early in adult life alongside their first strong impulses to protect, nourish, admire, and raise up a person outside their family and childhood friend commitments

@default_friend @radicalgusto I think almost everyone has felt intense, genuine, nonextinguishable, uncomfortably intense sexual desire, and that's enough of a seed for great sex that you can work with it to imagine great sex even if you've never had it

@radicalgusto @default_friend I wonder to what extent you can develop a richer sexuality out of romantic lit if you haven't had any great sex so far. My intuition is that it's doable, if the text cues your imagination properly. But it's fascinating that that could even be possible.

@radicalgusto @default_friend Well, hmm — it's really difficult to package a third-party "real sex" experience. I think @default_friend is right that it happens more often in lit than in film, possibly because readers sub in so much more of their own memory and imagination when they're consuming that way.
@default_friend (Or so my theory goes.)

@default_friend There's a real unmet demand for sex in film that isn't funny. That's actually hard to do, which is why so much porn is funny even when it accomplishes what it's there for. A guy hitting or choking a girl isn't funny, so it becomes a shortcut to "real" even when it's utterly fake
@default_friend The really sad thing is that it was... pretty much the only thing a generation and a half had to go on? I think we shuffled smoothly into Fifty Shades just to fucking feel something

@default_friend It looked at sex as a concept and asked why its dick wasn't hard while trying not to laugh. It was nihilistic and sad and funny only in the way that nihilistic and sad thing kinda have to make you laugh
@SlaytonBenjamin The fact that their parents *did* consent on their behalf doesn't make it acceptable; it makes them bad parents. I'm extremely comfortable with that judgment.

@SlaytonBenjamin People are reacting the way they're reacting not because this is successful marketing, but because it's outrageously unethical and arguably borderline criminal behavior that is likely to follow these kids forever. There's a reason you can't legally consent to this when you're 11.

text: @ergodicthought fwiw, the excerpt above is taken directly from episode 4 (which I think is probably the least charitable in the series)

What made this really frustrating listening for me is that many of the issues and concerns aren't frivolous, but they seem to point toward deeper community divisions and the friction between starkly divergent walks of life that *should* have been explored with less of an agenda

A really central bind is around degree of involvement: simultaneously, white parents are admonished for abandoning non-charter public schools... and, when they *do* decide to send their kids there, for being over-involved in both planning and fundraising

The whole thing is full of these really bizarre double or triple binds that are hard to untangle. White parents only *say* they're interested in diversity, they don't really care; and if they did, would it not be a sort of fetishism?

The closest the series gets to self-awareness is when a nonwhite mom is interviewed and seems confused or gently disinterested in diversity rather than the specific issues re: resources, class size, teacher quality, etc. that affect her kids' district. This happens several times
Nice White Parents is currently the #1 podcast on Apple, and this excerpt is a perfect encapsulation of its entire ethos https://t.co/nFop6K9CON

@Jonathan_Blow I agree that extraordinarily high taxes wouldn't be a dealbreaker for most of the ultra-wealthy if they were getting an unbeatable quality of life for it. CA used to at least gesture toward that idea, but the new cynical standard is "you'll come here for the network."
Can states actually tax nonresidents for visiting 1-2x/week? It seems a bit incredible

One of the weirdest features of CA's proposed wealth tax is that it also hits nonresidents who do a lot of business there. *Anyone* who visits 60 days out of any year is subjected to a prorated version of the tax, even though they are not entitled to the benefits of residency. https://t.co/gpIKVzt8Va
RT @JesseGalef: Kids will be kids.
@cmpndinterest @KellerScholl You know absolutely nothing about my life. Please remember that when you talk to people you find it particularly easy to pigeonhole.

@cmpndinterest @KellerScholl I think that's it for me. I have a massive backlog for this stuff, and I do think it's important, so it'll definitely be something I continue reading, thinking, and writing about.

@cmpndinterest @KellerScholl Why would I want to continue communicating with you? The way you've ignored my responses, put words in my mouth, and assumed positions I've never made makes me feel completely helpless to have a real conversation with you.

@cmpndinterest @KellerScholl I have not said what you're claiming to have said. I've made that *very* clear elsewhere. And I don't care in the slightest what color you are when I'm blocking someone for misrepresenting me.

@cmpndinterest @KellerScholl I don't have a strong opinion about reparations and I think I'd need to be much better read before I did.  People mean a lot of different things by them (cash, baby funds, community interventions) and expect different outcomes.
@cmpndinterest @KellerScholl I'm not saying that, and I'm going to block you if you keep putting words in my mouth. It's disingenuous, and in this context, extremely fucked up.

@cmpndinterest @KellerScholl Whoa. For one thing, I feel no special solidarity with white women, very few of whom I actually count among my friends. For another, AA has clearly had the greatest negative impact on Asian applicants, and I've spoken *repeatedly* about this.

@cmpndinterest @KellerScholl Real amends can never be made for something like slavery. It can't be reversed and it can't be reciprocated. So the conversation that proceeds from there has to be very clear on its terms and goals.
@cmpndinterest @KellerScholl I wouldn't know. I'm not a college grad.

@cmpndinterest @KellerScholl In general, if you're having to admit a group that's statistically underprepared in order to have that group at all, the solution lies upstream. Maybe family interventions/funding, probably a pretty dramatic overhaul for K-12.

@cmpndinterest @KellerScholl Are legacies "asking for a handout"? Maybe, but they obviously wouldn't see it that way.

I don't know the best way to correct existing disparities. I don't think that having universities admit students on the basis of anything but academic preparedness is a solution to anything.

@cmpndinterest @KellerScholl I don't think admissions to gatekeeping institutions are any way to make amends to anybody, just as they ought not be utilized to preserve specific families via legacies. Everybody seems perfectly happy to get just get theirs, of course.

@KellerScholl It sort of begs the question about why we're so set on using indirect proxies for these things, no? There are plenty if ADOS coming from wealthy, college-educated families, and plenty of refugees/illegal immigrants who are not.

@extranslocated Well, this is CA's ongoing struggle over prop 13: there are real challenges when you have a whole state full of "house rich, cash poor" people.

@Saporaku Capital gains assumes a transaction that generated cash. Income tax assumes a transaction that generated cash. There is a HUGE difference between that and a tax that hits illiquid assets that are hard to assess.

@Saporaku They can't evade through equity. Everything they own will be assessed, except for real estate. What they'll do is take up a primary residence in another state, maintain a secondary residence in CA, and avoid not only this tax but *all* of the taxes they used to pay to California.

text: @Saporaku Nothing stops them. That's my point.

@extranslocated Because wealth taxes have the unique ability to make you poorer YoY while creating unique challenges around paying them, as they're often targeting highly illiquid assets. An income tax or capital gains tax will never hit you for more than you made that year.
@Robert_t_Orr @ATabarrok Yes

@Robert_t_Orr @ATabarrok Uncertainty nets a wider spread of outcomes. But if you're running 40,000 simulations, the clusters will still be instructive. Can they tell you as much under high uncertainty? No. But if you run it again & assume tighter constraints for no good reason, you only confuse yourself.

@Robert_t_Orr @ATabarrok I'm starting to get the sense that nobody understands how models built on Monte Carlo simulations work. Obviously we'd be in a different situation if the election were tomorrow. The obvious fact is that it is not.

@Saporaku This is a much worse comparison. People move between states all the time. For wealthy people who already own multiple homes, it's something that can be planned within a week. It's just not comparable. You might as well run human drug trials on fish.

@patio11 As it turns out, these companies can sell you the product you want a lot easier than the product you *want to want.* In some sense, the ability to blame the product is a value add.

What I'd like is for us to drag these conversations into daylight and actually talk about what we want and what we don't want, without insisting that every mixed outcome of our preferred ideals is somebody else's fault.

The direction I see all this headed in, potentially, is that the sort of people who got their rocks off railing at religious institutions for "controlling women" will demand behind the scenes that certain female behavior be dampened on the algorithmic level "for their own good."

@TheAgeofShoddy The good news is that we can usually find some way to convince ourselves that people *aren't* actually acting freely, thus avoiding any serious self-reflection or reevaluation at the point of cognitive dissonance. Whew!

@TheAgeofShoddy Really, what we'd all love is to be unequivocally in favor of Important Freedoms without ever having to confront the fact that people may then act freely in a way we don't actually like very much.
@BillSeitz What's the right cap?

@aptifox He wants to be able to say he's for complete freedom of self-presentation. He doesn't want to admit that there were certain constraints that are probably for the best. As we all do, he's found a way to resolve cognitive dissonance without thinking too hard about the problem.
You might think it's bad that there's a product that offers that, and that's fine. What I'm asking you to do is to be honest about the nature of your complaint.

For the sake of not spending all day in the replies: if you think men didn't want to see lots and lots of partially-unclothed women in rapid succession until an algorithm offered it, I think you're silly

If you want a society that feels at least a little guilty hitting "like" on a 19-year-old in a schoolgirl costume, you're going to have to manage that on the culture layer. Demanding the tech layer fix it for you is begging for dystopia

I don't really have a strong opinion on the "best" settling point for a lot of these cultural norms, but the idea that whoever manages the Insta algo should be the one to figure that out seems... really, really bad?

text: If you have soreness in your hand or wrist, try feeling for a sore muscle just under your elbow. Apply comfortable pressure with your other thumb and then move your hand forward and back, clench and unclench your fist, gently flex your fingers against a hard surface, etc.

Self-massage tips:

- palpate "upstream" of the discomfort (for example, I have a sore spot above my foot that seems connected to a muscle I can feel under my knee)

- instead of rubbing, apply gentle pressure while playing with range of motion (rotating limb, stretching, etc.)

text: Related: the use of role-playing games to teach history — students take on the roles and arguments of historical figures, but are free to play with them and produce new outcomes (while understanding the divergence from history) https://t.co/Yvig2wN5c8
@MarkNoronha To be clear, I think this is probably the right sort of question for this project: tradeoffs and incentive structures that can be modified, but with many unexpected challenges.
@MarkNoronha What in particular? Alternatives to habitat destruction? Extinction broadly?

I'm thinking about putting together a class/toolkit on "simulations" — basically, simplified & gamified versions of real-world problems that kids can play with and compete on, based on the work of world-class instructor Josh Dahn.

@Nick_Yawn @StephenUlmerII I've talked to a lot of teachers and administrators. They have diverse opinions on the matter, but you're frankly wrong if you think they don't want more freedom to experiment in the classroom. Did you know that private school instructors are paid *less* than public, on average?

Parents know what their kids look like when they're "in the zone" re: the thrill of learning something or developing their mastery of some skill. The real question is why they feel so helpless to find or create a situation where they're in that mode most of the time.

It's easy enough to recalibrate. Is the kid coming home exhausted but energized, desperate to keep chewing or working on the day's ideas? Or is he defeated? A child that can be described as "defeated" should be the abnormality. We've let it become *much* too close to the norm.

I think the two are related, because once a parent feels permitted to be fully driven by their love for their child, unobscured by external expectations and social pressures, it becomes a bit clearer what the goal ought to be and how it can be aimed at. Excuses fall away.

Separately, we're still grappling with a crisis over the purpose of education: Is it to produce expert test-takers with a vast range of narrow skills, or to hone the natural human capacity for reflection, adaptation, problem-solving and iterative self-refinement?

The tragedy is that the pressure on wealthy parents to not give their kids an education that sets them apart reduces experimentation for better schools/alternatives. We've deemed education "too important" to ever be improved by the processes that improve other goods & services. https://t.co/xykD3skJTa
(I'm vaguetweeting podgate. Can I call it podgate? I'm calling it podgate.)

If ever there were a sign of societal failure to thrive, it's a culture that castigates parents for doing whatever they can to ensure their own children have a safe, supportive, happy learning environment.
@bramcohen I have no idea why every comment from you on this thread is a misdirection or misinterpretation of the response prior, but I'm blocking. Sorry if you're just having an off day.

@bramcohen I think you're actually just extrapolating whatever you need to in order to disagree with me now. And I'm responding, even though I think your comment is low value. I'm not sure why twitter does this to people.

text: @t_voight I'm sorry for your loss. She sounds like an incredible person. I really hope to someday be the kind of mom whose son feels this way about me.

@HectorRosekrans @annwoodshive If we simply cannot have them safely, then we have to bear that together. Everyone. No exceptions. And if we *can*, we have to figure out how to help families have them responsibly.

@HectorRosekrans @annwoodshive A man who raises his kids loved is more than enough. He becomes a central node in a network that will suffer tremendously for his loss, and funerals allow that loss to be distributed and shared and acknowledged. They're a timeless ritual for a reason.

@HectorRosekrans @annwoodshive Thank you both for your comments here. Certain people have immense gifts, ambition, and perseverance that I think can be fairly rewarded with outsized influence, but that isn't what funerals are about. It doesn't call for an exception with regard to the celebration of the life.
@reflected_sky That's a good point.

@KBSoundToys I haven't scrolled through beyond the first few, so I'm a bit naive, but: literally everything with significant media coverage has become a tribal commodity in one way or another. I'm sure a lot of people clamp onto this because it's John Lewis, or because it's the democrats.

@TheAgeofShoddy It's hard when you're starting out, though! What's reasonable? What's "normal"? I reflect on what I put up with from my first boyfriends and wonder what I could possibly have been thinking. Maybe it would've been different if I'd seen a healthy relationship at home, but alas.

@InquisitiveUrsa It's the UV. As with everything else, it's hard to say with high certainty — but there is now considerable evidence that the same UV rays found in sunlight destroy the virus fairly quickly.

text: @jcbarret This is a good point, and if there were a much better established alternative protocol, or even much stronger contenders that aren't doomed to be prohibitively limited for some time, I don't think I'd be nearly as defensive of the ongoing research process for hydroxychloroquine.
@jessicamalonso Yep, I think so. And it's pretty difficult to evaluate either claim, unfortunately.

@jcbarret AFAICT, the claims made by proponents (recently) are that it should be given prior to hospitalization and as early as possible — and/or that it should be used prophylactically. (I don't believe there's a common claim that it will prevent illness vs. just making it tolerable.)

@jcbarret This is an interesting situation wherein even proponents of the drug are (sometimes, perhaps often?) claiming that dose and progression of illness are critical factors in determining whether it should be given at all, while still seeming overly zealous on its efficacy.

@jcbarret It's difficult to gain high confidence in a timeframe this short, not only because RCTs are expensive and hard to organize, but also because a "treatment" isn't just the drug: it's also the dose given, at what point in the progression of the illness, and to which kind of patient.

@radfugee Yes, but I think we might be talking past each other on this one. My claim isn't that physicians have to be passive until they can make a particular decision with very high confidence. It's that high confidence is extremely difficult to achieve in a timeframe this short.
@radfugee It is additive, certainly.

text: @hotgirlintech Their conclusion is not that protests don't spread coronavirus, but that non-protesters seem to be more likely to stay in during mass protest events. They even suggest that this may be due in part to declining mental health. The coverage on this has been godawful.

At this point, urban centers need to figure out what policy is sustainable on a timescale of *years* and start moving toward that. The days of "if we just do this for 6-8 weeks..." are over. Cities like SF got their 2 months of solid compliance and they largely squandered it.

text: Meanwhile, people who follow the rules can protect *themselves* from the virus, but at the cost of nearly every protective factor we've identified against the ever-rising "deaths of despair": suicide, alcoholism and drug abuse. And without broader compliance, COVID still spikes.

Basically, the sum of the available toolkit in the US amounts only to half-measures, and those measures are the same ones that are leaving [probably lifelong] scars on the earning potential of new entrants to the labor market + upwardly-mobile blue collar biz owners + their staff

text:
In SF, people are still not permitted to gather in groups of >12. Even outdoors. Even with full mask & distancing compliance. Even for weddings. Even for funerals.

Whatever you think of the protests, they have *got* to be wearing down the sense of solidarity required for this.

@patio11 Again, the community may know, acknowledge & appreciate the people effectively bankrolling it, but they're not viewed as moral leaders or central figures just for spending money, and a lot of donor "perks" that'd be considered normal in other contexts would be seen as perverse

@patio11 Generally speaking, places where awe of money is significant enough to cause purchasing power to funge with community involvement are not what I am personally describing when I talk about highly functional communities

@skot75 I'm trying to avoid misinterpretation, but maybe just making myself hard to read. What I mean is that people are working with a lot of social animal hardware that evolved in small groups, and we're prone to think we can ignore that stuff to create material solutions that scale
@tjrwriting @s_r_constantin ~22-45
@s_r_constantin Most people in this situation I've talked to are unmarried men with no children, fwiw

Disclaimer: most things/services that people need can be bought with money. Trade is not bad. Money is not bad. Donating money is not bad. It's very good! I just think a lot of people are running up against the challenges of overly explicitly/scalably organizing social primates

@patio11 If I try to think of a good counterexample — say, an introverted, unmarried crypto millionaire who donates $ & participates in some community activities — I don't see that person being understood as a "pillar of the community," though they may be well appreciated & acknowledged

@patio11 AFAICT, in highly functional communities it's generally not possible for wealthy people to purchase moral standing with cash alone. The social obligation can be in the form of offering good work terms, freeing up a prosocial spouse to be heavily community-involved, etc

People seem a lot better off when the ways they give help and receive help are fluid and generally nonmonetary, such that they don't have to allow themselves to be bilked by consistent game-players or feel like they're a "drain" on some system themselves

Volunteerism is typically pretty good for people and a lot closer to the mark, but it still relies on a very clear persisting distinction between "helper" and "helped" that doesn't seem to be so readily salient in the healthiest families/friendships/microcommunities

Shower thought: while Gofundme is probably generally a good thing, it really relies on commodifying one's situation to meet a new market for community participation as a kind of luxury good literally purchased in dollars

I know *a lot* of culturally and intellectually secular people who are adopting religion just to have some semblance of a safety net built on being seen, understood and cared for as an individual rather than just being a diligent taxpayer or someone who constantly upskills https://t.co/BZk9p2gH8K

I think it'd actually be sort of nice if people didn't have to function as personal PR machines or strangely isolated intellectual combatants with most of their mental energy. Didn't people do non-meta work at some point? Didn't we like that?
I think it's fair to ask how utterly fucked up your life is to become once you put out a single assertion, question, or joust that can fit within the constraint of 280 characters

If you're asking the question, the answer is — tragically, cynically, pathetically

text: I mean this seriously: banning homeschooling is a pick-up-and-leave level red flag. It's no secret how poor US child education is, nor how physically and psychologically unsafe schools can be. Parents absolutely must retain the right to say "no more, my child is being harmed." https://t.co/O9ZQAcLUjM
@outputrotation Some do that, some just rotate through the parents (more feasible for younger kids)

Many families will experiment with community pods out of necessity: keeping kids home every other weekday or cutting days in half just won't be feasible for most working parents. But I predict that so many kids will start thriving in pods that schools will entice very few back.

@poiThePoi The public education system already employs a tremendous number of people, many of whom do no direct instruction. I've mostly lost the sense that K-12 system is efficient even if the only metric is a freed up labor force.

text: @yabubian I don't see how it does, but if you believe this that's your prerogative.

@yabubian Insofar as China has racist cultural attitudes to confront, it's hardly alone in the world — but it's pure fantasy to pretend these are non-issues except when pointed externally in order to benefit the ruling party.
@yabubian Nonsense. I have a full laundry list of valid concerns with regard to the CCP, but I simply don't equate citizenship with ethnicity or governments with their people.

@yabubian Oh, believe me, my concerns with the CCP extend far beyond "only" foreign user data. I'm not remotely shy when it comes to my criticisms of this regime. If my mistake was too narrow a scope, I will try very hard to correct it.

@yabubian I would no sooner assign guilt for racism to all Chinese than to all Americans, but the extent to which discriminatory treatment is tolerated or endorsed is an orthogonal question that I'm not afraid to look at squarely. If you're going to put words in my mouth, think first.

@yabubian Excuse me? The mixed and often uncomfortable experiences of the incredibly minute percentage of black people living in China are well-documented. Tell me: am I to be considered an obvious racist for ignoring them, or for hearing them?

@yabubian No, because the moral character or intentions of the people running TikTok have absolutely no bearing on whether or not that data is available to the CCP. I don't begrudge anyone working with what they've got, but I'm not going to play stupid.

text: If you can find a way to believe it, it'll also serve you very well to know that nearly everyone is full of pain and managing it to varying degrees of success. Money or success never spared anybody tragedy. Truly. So try to be warm and gentle even with the people "above" you

Start helping other people in small ways right away. Really listen to people and think about who you know that could help them do what they're trying to do. Sincerely hope the people around you meet their highest potential, even if it's greater than yours

My advice: consume a lot of information, let yourself get rabbitholed. Read, think, and write a lot, but don't make it a chore. Reach out to your heroes, but also to people who produce great but less recognized work. Don't belittle yourself. Write emails you'd want to receive.

When everyone is trying to convince you that your circumstances will doom you to mediocrity or failure, that the world is rigged against you, that nobody who can help you will ever help someone *like* you... tuning all of that out is a legitimate superpower

@backspaceTab22 @balajis @chr1sa This was not a point that was considered in the CSC case and it has no bearing on the ruling and the precedent set by it. Recommend reading the link above!
@backspaceTab22 @balajis @chr1sa Whether a civil suit could be approached in a similar way, I don't know

@backspaceTab22 @balajis @chr1sa This was a criminal rather than civil case & the question was whether the state of California could enforce its two-party consent law with regard to a call originating from + recorded in Georgia. The ruling determined that yes, California can prosecute under those circumstances.
@backspaceTab22 @balajis @chr1sa That's just not how this case was evaluated or the ruling determined. It's not a bad theory, but it's not the precedent that was set.
@backspaceTab22 @balajis @chr1sa "The California decision confirms that states with restrictive eavesdropping laws will not hesitate to enforce those laws against interstate callers."

@backspaceTab22 @balajis @chr1sa This question was the entire basis of the SC case, and the ruling determined "that the complaint was properly governed by California law" and could be prosecuted in CA despite the recording party calling from Georgia.
@backspaceTab22 @balajis @chr1sa It's at least true for CA, where the state supreme court specifically ruled on the issue in 2006 https://t.co/1E5WEGMXm2
@visakanv I think I can count the friends this probably *isn't* on one hand

@backspaceTab22 @balajis @chr1sa If the recorded speech is taking place in a two-party consent state — including CA, where many Clubhouse members are located — the person recording can be prosecuted regardless of where they're physically located. The critical issue is whether or not CH convos are "confidential"

Like "abolish" and "defund," the symbolic use of "shut down" tells you what's permitted to sit on the societal chopping block. You can plug in anything, and see how it feels.

Shut down ______. See if you can say "shut down women," for example, without feeling the twinge. https://t.co/XTgL1MVHB0
@lat66south I don't know what you think "shut down" or "symbolic" mean. But I'm betting it's way easier for you, broadly, if they don't mean much of anything.

And the loop closes with "shut down STEM." The institutions tasked with nurturing the human project make a symbolic display of their willingness to kill it to suit the tastes of the moment. https://t.co/9dUl9yT8nT

@DavidDeutschOxf Anger and self-loathing are really strange emotional states to be locked in long term. I don't think human beings who fee they can move freely socially often experience them for extended periods. I think that might warp a lot of other perception

@DavidDeutschOxf Yes, and I don't necessarily believe that destructive networks inherently have an edge over generative/creative networks, but I do think a lot of current cultural settings make destruction feel more accessible/participatory than creative activity, which is... not good at all

note: I use the phrase "death cults" a lot; it's my very broad term for mass social behavior/organization that leads people to fetishize political or physical destruction, self-destruction, or literal physical death.

A thought experiment I've heard a few times: if each person could press a button to destroy the world, how many people would have their go before the world ended?

Arguably, mass communication is allowing the creation of fractional buttons, along with little networked death cults https://t.co/LqaTM10hV2

@ccachor2 Yeah, progressive city leadership is absolutely collapsing in several major metro areas simultaneously. The semi-public struggle sessions and the palpable fear of mob reprisals are not leaving many with the sense that these are stable places to start businesses or raise families.

text: @CrnchyMama @BAPearlmutter A kid who loves French will probably speak French, a kid who loves bass will probably play bass. Most kids are not doing what they love in school. For those who do, it may be a good place for them, though of course they could learn what they love more effectively with tutoring.

@CrnchyMama @BAPearlmutter I think it's a bit extraordinary to think kids taught directly in a group of 5 by a PhD student or professor are doomed to become useless in comparison to anyone with a public K-12 education, especially given Bloom's 2 sigma problem and other related research. Worth testing, no?

text: @EmmaJP9_ @auderdy @mechanicalmonk1 Latter point hints at the crux of the issue to me, which is whether it's a good idea to try to educate children by way of models so sparse they don't even stand up to good questions. The problem is that most *adults* never realize that these aren't even good simplifications

@auderdy @mechanicalmonk1 Better to work with symbols that remind you what you don't know, e.g. "that mysterious thing that makes the toy move." Otherwise it seems we're prone to assuming we understand whatever we have the words to talk about, which makes it easy to end up w/ a schooling system like ours

@auderdy @mechanicalmonk1 You can easily learn the concept before the label for it, but if you learn the label before the concept, you just have some phonemes or a scribble. If you think you have any more than that, you're tricking yourself in the way I discussed above
@auderdy @mechanicalmonk1 What do you mean by "working on the realm of communication between people" and "borders of a concept" here? This is going meta lol

@auderdy @mechanicalmonk1 "Symbols are useful" & "symbols are useful even when you don't know what they mean" are two different claims. The latter is sometimes true, but often not, and they risk putting you in a position where you've forgotten what you don't know

@auderdy @mechanicalmonk1 "Energy makes the toy move" is just a restatement of the unsolved "x makes the toy move," and it's one that actually makes most people worse off:
if they ask a friend "what is energy?" they'll get a less applicable answer than "what makes the toy move?"
@auderdy @mechanicalmonk1 This is great!
@auderdy @mechanicalmonk1 I don't care of it's Feynman, as stated it's not a reasonable claim. Maybe context would help.

@auderdy @mechanicalmonk1 I don't see much of a correlation between what you wrote and what you screencapped; distinguishing between symbol and symbolized doesn't imply that symbols are useful without a working understanding of what they reference, however thinly functional
@auderdy @mechanicalmonk1 fwiw if I understand you, I think you're 100% wrong here

Like, if you wanted to create the educational equivalent of a rudimentary philosophical zombie — someone who could roughly approximate a person with an understanding of how a physical phenomenon works without actually understanding it — this is how you'd do it...?

Weird how much of what's taught formally about physical phenomena is reduced purely to the symbolic layer: e.g. memorize the name of the thing x that does y, memorize the name of phenomenon y, label x on the same vastly oversimplified line drawing you saw in the book.
@BarryPCotter @paulg @bryan_caplan @Ed_Realist @robinhanson They have to succeed at that; otherwise, it's impossible for 1-2 adults to manage 20-30+ children.

@BarryPCotter @paulg @bryan_caplan @Ed_Realist I spent a stint assuming that schools were trying to turn children into the "wrong" thing but, frankly, even if they are they're not doing any of it effectively. It's a place for kids to twiddle their thumbs while mom and dad work, with a calcified corporate hierarchy doing admin

@EskSF @SuperPACman_ @christinevans @samklew Now, maybe the mayor and fire chief are lying about the apparent migration issue. Why would they? Beats me. It sure doesn't make them look good or reduce the demand for their resources. But if you believe they're lying, say so, and explain why. "Tropes" are tropes for a reason.

@EskSF @SuperPACman_ @christinevans @samklew I'm in favor of mobilizing resources to prevent homeless people from winding up in situations where it's virtually impossible for them to get their needs met & be safe from the virus. Hotels can have a big role there. But we need to be utterly neutral on the facts on the ground.

@SuperPACman_ @noah_arroyo @EskSF @christinevans @samklew We *cannot* pattern-match to "the progressive response" or "the conservative response" and proceed reflexively. We have to manage a very bad situation sustainably, so we don't watch the support system collapse after taking care of a few thousand people for a few months.

@SuperPACman_ @noah_arroyo @EskSF @christinevans @samklew We're managing a very vulnerable population in a shockingly expensive way, staring down the barrel at an est $1.7B budget shortfall, tremendous health consequences for a growing population living on the street & a huge number of residents who'll be in the same situation very soon

@SuperPACman_ @noah_arroyo @EskSF @christinevans @samklew They just don't think it through. What happens when a 65-year-old with diabetes comes from Stockton, attempts to enter the system, and is turned away? What are the mayor's incentives, what are the media's incentives, what are that individual's incentives?

@noah_arroyo @SuperPACman_ @EskSF @christinevans @samklew Most places aren't offering anything remotely like this. The chance of a free private room with three square meals delivered is not low, it's zero. The weather is mild, services are quite strong, there's time to wait. Try to put yourself in the shoes of someone in this situation.

text: I'm suspicious of "niceness" in certain contexts, often because I'm picking up that a particular conversation isn't about sharing ideas but about testing the threat detection system of a somewhat fluid zeitgeist; "nice" is not play, it's showing the teeth without the growl (yet)

this morning's shower thought is that it's a little bit funny that my overactive anti-ideological immune system — now acting on ultra-progressive urban SFBA — was actually trained on ultra-conservative rural Missouri, years ago

@FearIsNotPanic IMO it's very reasonable to say "I can't trust the government to catch me" if you've been semi-regularly missed before and the consequences this time may ruin your life. Again, I think this is a very difficult hypothetical to run as though it were real if, for you, it isn't.

fwiw I was (and continue to be) an early advocate of short-term lockdowns as needed to control hospital overwhelm, but the week-over-week cost to the most vulnerable doesn't merely grow linearly, and we have to respect how much we're forcing onto these folks' shoulders

@FearIsNotPanic A lot of people will be in situations where they cannot manage their problems with aid because they're not eligible, their particular region is under-resourced or their needs are great. Realistically, "open most things up" is a safer bet for many than "trust gov to fill cracks."

e.g. Have you considered stealing, selling illegal goods or selling sex in order to make some money? Have you considered staying with a potentially dangerous person in order to have a place to sleep? There are people who will have to consider these because they cannot work.

busywork + "self-discipline" as often used (though less applicable in certain ambitious circles), cancel culture, tall poppy syndrome, the idea of fundamental human fungibility (see linked tweet) — all weapons against taste https://t.co/CRXBnC84OE

children hear "that won't work" and "never give up!" all the time,* and unless they realize that these are deployed as needed to counter the internal sense that you should try something that seems fun or stop doing something that you're not enjoying, it only generates confusion

when you are trained very young to allow your superiors to waste your time, you are learning that your taste isn't functional; it's a hunger that will only pain you or make you do bad things

other people will tell you what matters and what needs to be done

taste admittedly introduces a lot of risk at the individual level and a degree of instability at the population level: progress of any kind is necessarily destabilizing, moreso when people disagree about what it ought to look like

entity.name: His Dark Materials
entity.description: Secrets and dangers lie ahead for young Lyra Belacqua in an epic tale of stolen children and the mysterious substance of Dust.

text: it's a bit like the daemons in His Dark Materials; you can certainly struggle to get along with someone whose taste is very different from yours, but the real battle is to protect all taste

the "taste" I'm referring to is the thing that tells you that your circumstances aren't working and how you want them to be different

this leads to all kinds of people, from maker-hermits to eccentric rainbow-clad extroverts to techies who become obsessed with making holograms

it took me longer to realize why I found this so viscerally *creepy*

people like @visakanv @auderdy @pmarca @micsolana @HeatherEHeying & many others led me to the conclusion that "taste" is a real + important thing, a kind of intuitive discernment that's trained over a lifetime

when I started researching child ed, one of the first things to strike me was how much of children's time we wasted

soon after came the distressing realization that a lot of people find this functional, discipline defined as an unconditional willingness to do nonsense work

they sure didn't like it when we were 11, but "you can't make me" was always the right answer

"you'll inevitably give up" and "never give up!" are memes applied reflexively & almost arbitrarily to prevent an internal locus of discernment from developing properly https://t.co/t0TJ2LBmgq

text: @micsolana @PaulRoales Free travel/standard quarantine restrictions are also a big deal, but confining citizens to their homes with the exception of a few approved activities amounts to house arrest without due process. I think we're seeing very few citations for fear of serious future settlements

What we're supposed to be buying ourselves with an emergency toolkit that approaches the power of all-out martial law is the ability to deliver a rapid + flexible **short-term** response at whatever scale/scope makes the most sense. Not indefinite unannounced Martial Law Lite.

text: The problem isn't strong political tools for emergency response, the problem is the fundamental lack of respect for what they are. It's a big deal to suspend the right to assemble. Announcing at 40 days locked down that you still have no plan except more lockdown is unforgivable.

You're being daft if you think you can invoke emergency that functionally suspend rights **for months or years** without having to eat the implications later, either in the form of a flood of lawsuits or a shiny new semi-autocracy
I know we're not supposed to say it out loud because the virus might be listening but it is actually very very very not-constitutional for the mayor to make having a friend over a crime

@muddletoes The only reason to be upset that I called you the target of this ad is that your understanding of how it works makes pretty unfavorable assumptions about its audience. I think those assumptions are wrong, and the ad could never feasibly work on those terms

@muddletoes I'm not sure else how I'm supposed to interpret the assumption that a person who might read this billboard has never considered that their beliefs may not be correct, but will do so now that they've seen a billboard. People know when they're being called stupid this blatantly.

@muddletoes I'm not saying you're a "sheeple," I'm saying you're the target of this ad. The fact that you think the target of this ad is best described as "sheeple" is exactly why I think your explanation of how it's supposed to work is wrong.

Life is really fucking hard for a lot of folks. This is one kind of life that a lot of young men are living, explained by the people living it. I think you should watch it, because I don't think you're likely to be able to avoid the cultural insistence that you judge these people

text: @basus @BasilMarte @TheAnnaGat SpaceX wouldn't get nearly as much attention if it were *just* beating out ULA on launch price using standard tech. It's not hard to see why people are excited about it, nor is it difficult to understand why the many sensitive launches the US gov contracts aren't going to India.

@TheAnnaGat @basus I see a really weird cultural shift toward the toxic assumption that *attempting something big* as an individual is fundamentally at odds with democracy, that individual heroism itself is a sort of social defection, and at the very least nobody should be rewarded for it. Bizarre
@basus @TheAnnaGat I personally have some doubt that *this* guy has the balls, but I live to be proven wrong https://t.co/Bsw6Pl40m3

@basus @TheAnnaGat I invite anyone who'd like to test their personal bias/privilege to infect themselves with guinea worm and share their thoughts about how much esteem, status or cultural importance someone who eliminates that parasite should be "allowed" to get.

@basus @TheAnnaGat I leave it to Anna to be cordial and to stop tagging me if she doesn't want the bad cop to show up, but for my piece I have zero remaining tolerance for trust fund navel-gazers who have Serious Concerns about the people who aren't moving resources toward solutions the "right" way

@basus @TheAnnaGat I struggle to fathom how much of a loser you'd have to be to even consider writing this piece, and to be immoral enough to actually do it is just straight-up beyond my imaginative capacity

text: @basus @TheAnnaGat Guinea worm disease hit 3.5M people in 1986. Here's how that goes: you drink contaminated water. Larvae eat through your intestine. Mature worms eat through your skin; you reintroduce them to water to cool the searing pain. CDC & Gates collaborated. 51 cases worldwide in 2019.

Maybe someone needs to sit down with these admins and explain that if your primary goal is to maintain an outrageously large estate with which to lavish wealth on people you've promised lifelong employment, that's... something... but it's not really what people think a school is

...but they could at least work with their donors to make use of their dragon treasure nest-scale investment schemes, especially considering that virtually everyone else isn't sitting on a pile of gold right now

I don't claim to be an expert on this, but I'm told that it's the norm for these colleges & universities to have almost unfathomably large liabilities that are absolutely iron-tight. They can't pivot to being lighter weight outfits even if it's the only move that makes any sense

As some friends in the ed space have been pointing out, wealthy international students have really bulked out tuition income for US schools & neither they nor their American counterparts are going to love the idea of paying 5 figures for a makeshift Zoom freshman year https://t.co/GI7iXXeSS4

@hanlonbt I don't know or care how you raise money. Obviously I don't think Marc was your intended audience here, which is part of this reason I've been pointing out how disingenuous this looks. Again, disappointing.

@hanlonbt It's not intent, it's literally the content. Twisting it into a pitch for cash for lobbying is already a bit gross; framing it as a legitimate criticism is straight-up disingenuous. It's disappointing.
@hanlonbt If your intention was just to preach to your choir, fine. But I just unfollowed and I'm frankly increasingly soured. A little intellectual honestly would be lovely these days.

@hanlonbt "The main problems are cultural and political."

This is a "build something or shut up" piece. It wasn't written for you, which is why I think it's both disingenuous to pretend that it was and naive to think you could possibly have any leverage with this line of argumentation.

Taken at face value, "grow what's working" and "fix what's broken" are both perfectly sensible. What it comes down to, I think, is whether or not you believe that increasing resources tends to ameliorate systemic problems rather than just obscuring them
There's an underappreciated semi-partisan divide over whether it's broadly more useful to move money/resources toward small things that are working or big things that are failing

@hanlonbt I understand the ostensible purpose of the lobbying layer, I understand that it's tremendously expensive to lobby the SFBA or CA broadly to do *anything,* I like your stated mission. But god damn I'm tired of seeing this article purposely misread in this fashion.

@aeroquacious @AustenLamacraft @jcrichman @fuehrerking @AlanHogan Broad suggestion for anyone else reading this: if you know someone who seems deeply interested in the experiences and happiness of children but doesn't have any, try to put two and two together

@aeroquacious @AustenLamacraft @jcrichman @fuehrerking @AlanHogan Briefly unblocking you to let you know I've struggled for years with the loss of a long-term relationship & some quite severe problems with my fertility.

I'm sure this seemed like a good point to you. You may or may not know how much time I've spent with kids. But bad call.

@AustenLamacraft @jcrichman @fuehrerking @AlanHogan Welp, I'm done. I can't tell if you're being disingenuous or just having a hard time contextualizing what I'm saying, but either way I don't think it's worth continuing here.

@AustenLamacraft @jcrichman @fuehrerking @AlanHogan All this converges on a pretty fundamental theme — if you restrain your child from making their own choices, they'll never have practice making good ones or experience making bad ones. If you insist they're not agent-y enough to direct themselves, the prophecy will fulfill itself

@AustenLamacraft @jcrichman @fuehrerking @AlanHogan Somewhere upthread Jeffrey noted how crazy it would be to leave a child in a casino with a credit card, and I found myself thinking: why?

If your child can't be trusted to *that* degree, something has gone very, very wrong.

@AustenLamacraft @jcrichman @fuehrerking @AlanHogan But frankly I'm really fucking tired of people enjoying the oddness of my life from afar while insisting that they and their kids are too stupid, "normal," reckless or passive to stop going through the motions themselves and start playing a little bit

@AustenLamacraft @jcrichman @fuehrerking @AlanHogan Based on what you've said here, I suspect your intuitions about these things are terribly, terribly off. Maybe I'm broadly wrong; maybe your path to happiness and fulfillment is much more standard and requires subservience to certain norms that don't work for me.

text:
@AustenLamacraft @jcrichman @fuehrerking @AlanHogan It's *impossible* for anyone to predict the future in which their kids will operate

The entire point of the thread I linked below the original tweet is that this begs us to have some humility

@AustenLamacraft @jcrichman @fuehrerking @AlanHogan The reality is that *most* of the constraints children operate under have little or nothing to do with their health and safety. They reflect parents working very hard to fulfill social expectations and guide their children down a path that made sense approx one generation ago.

@AustenLamacraft @jcrichman @fuehrerking @AlanHogan Parents regularly fail to keep their children within those bounds while excluding nearly all of their options for pursuing enjoyment. Case in point: the sheer number who literally give their prepubescent children amphetamines because a school administrator said they ought to.
@AustenLamacraft @jcrichman @fuehrerking @AlanHogan I'm guessing it doesn't occur to you what an utterly joyless way this is to describe a human life

@AustenLamacraft @jcrichman @fuehrerking @AlanHogan You might think this is my first rodeo, but I've had a lot of arguments/discussions with people convinced that life must be rather well-disciplined and fairly unpleasant to be functional. I do not know why these people follow a woman who lives in a chapel full of ducks and moths.

@AustenLamacraft @jcrichman @fuehrerking @AlanHogan I can imagine plenty of cases where the latter is "worse" on my terms than the former, the former "worse" than the latter, and neither/both worth the time. Rather than go neurotic over it, I do what I want to do within semi-reasonable bounds for health, safety & sustainability.

@AustenLamacraft @jcrichman @fuehrerking @AlanHogan More importantly, is there room for childhood at all in a world where the worthiness of any person's activities is evaluated on their potential to meet a plausible future need, however unlikely?

@fuehrerking @AlanHogan I had to disable a net nanny, which I wish I could say required mAd hAX. I actually just persuaded an adult friend in Singapore to walk me through a troubleshooting process until we cracked it

@shellscape All that said, I don't know you or your child and it could easily be the case that computers aren't a particular interest. Many children would prefer to draw, or dance, or make music, and fortunately parents are under no pressure to stop them from pursuing those doggedly.

@shellscape I'm sure you feel you're doing what you feel you need to do to be the sort of parent want to be, and assuming that'll produce the sort of child you are supposed to produce. My parents had similar assumptions and I'm trying very hard to learn to forgive them for it.

@shellscape The extreme pressure on parents to neither helicopter-parent nor neglect while in many cases acting as the enforcement mechanism for at-home busywork and no longer having any cultural support for providing unsupervised time is... toxic, at best. Childhood is largely lost.

@shellscape What you're describing here is the importance of limiting screen time such that you perform better as a parent — specifically, avoiding laziness. This has very little to do with kids, many of whom would benefit considerably from "lazier" parents.

It's quite often the case that when a reporter gets a story "wrong," there never was any way to get it right; getting the story right would turn it into a non-story

As motivations go, influencing the narrative may seem better than driving up pageviews, but it still means constantly needing to either discover or manufacture novel stories. And one of those is a lot easier to do than the other

The main difference: I don't think a typical journalist finds it rewarding to have his or work panned, even if it results in a spike on the analytics dash that would be nice if it weren't the result of viral loathing

I think the assumption that journalists write controversial content for clicks is mostly wrong. I think they largely do it to assert influence on the narrative that makes up shared mainstream/tribe reality, something that neither blasé nor universally-derided work accomplishes
