text: @liron I have a hard time believing the typical person in an imperfect lockdown (e.g. semi-protected grocery runs, housemates) is getting a particularly large dose. Makes sense for health workers, grocery workers, etc.

@maxniederhofer No way 6 months. Maybe 12, *if* plasma treatments pan out and the FDA starts playing ball. People need their checks yesterday, and they can't be a one-off. "Suspend rent" if you like, slumlords will still crack kneecaps.

@liron I'm not confident enough to be against it, but I'd look at it more like military service than a no-brainer. Permanent damage to the lungs and/or heart are real possibilities. You'd very plausibly be trading end-of-life years for cash or civic duty.

@NoblePublius No. It's going to be much higher than that, assuming exponential growth.

Why? Same issue as before. You can expect that roughly half of your extant cases were contracted in the last week. Eventually lockdowns stretch that timespan.

@NoblePublius Consider this: average 1 week of incubation, up to 2 weeks; 1 week or so mild symptoms, 2 weeks severe symptoms. So if x% test positive asymptomatic, should we assume a quarter of those are still in the incubation period?

@NoblePublius Even countries like Iceland that have taken to mass testing warn that a case that tests positive without symptoms may or may not present with symptoms later on. Unless you know the date of exposure, it's anyone's guess whether you're a "true" asymptomatic case or still incubating

@NoblePublius If you have a massive % of the population exposed, incubated + asymptomatic, you can expect the duration of the crisis to be shorter, but the severity to be no less acute. But there's no solid evidence that that's the case.
@maxniederhofer People will be evicted, threatened by debtors, start violating stay-at-home orders, kill themselves. Where I come from, 2 years without income is no joke.

@NoblePublius Analyzing deaths vs. recoveries will overestimate CFR, because deaths happen faster than recoveries. Analyzing deaths vs. total cases will underestimate CFR, because new cases happen faster than deaths from prior cohorts.

text: @NoblePublius Cohort, not demographic. If in fact you're dealing with exponential growth, the bulk of your cases should be expected to be newer. Nobody is dying of this during the incubation period. Nobody is dying of this during the first week or so of relatively mild symptoms.
@NoblePublius GTFO unless you're looking at cohorts

@StephenPiment I don't see this as a good thing, necessarily; I think there's a decent chance we're clipping some life years off the median person >40 years of age who catches this and recovers. But it's inevitable.

Lockdown can't persist until a validated treatment or vaccine.

I take COVID very seriously, and I don't think it's reasonable to pursue herd immunity. But we need to start seeing some solid proposals for the next phase of the war.

text:
@JasonStutman @Jason Not.
True.

I don't know how to be any clearer.

I agree that staff limits slows the movement of bodies. I disagree on what can be concluded from that w/o more info.

I didn't say anything about Central Park, and I block people who lie about what I've said. Cardinal sin. Bye bro. https://t.co/9S4LalOiuZ
@JasonStutman @Jason https://t.co/1Se15DHFCe
@JasonStutman @Jason Anyway, I don't play games with people who keep their goal posts on wheels. Have fun, kids.

@JasonStutman @Jason To what degree? Cutting back to strictly essential staff will slow all these processes, certainly. But it's not going to account for maxing out space in freezer trucks.

Your claim was that funeral homes are refusing bodies because it's not profitable to take them. False.

@JasonStutman @Jason Everyone is reporting overstuffed funeral homes. NY is sending the national guard to seize PPE from upstate hospitals whether they like it or not, you think NYC funeral homes are in any position to decline bodies? Please.

@JasonStutman @Jason It's clearly both. 1 is false; funeral homes are overflowing. 2 may be a contributing factor, but would hardly matter if deaths were a rounding error on top of anticipated all-cause mortality. Mass burials in parks are not a topic of conversation during a bad flu season.

@JasonStutman @Jason For reference, NYC had a morgue capacity of 900, and that's worked just fine for them prior to this — that should give you a sense of how mortality has exploded in the city in the past 2-3 weeks

text: @m8popkin @ESYudkowsky If you think you can look at a quote and determine on the basis of the eloquence/coherence of the language surrounding it whether it was actually said, you're either unjustifiably naive or possess cognitive powers far beyond my own

@oscredwin @politicalmath Slower/low rate of recovery post-catastrophe for news outlets, necessary bailouts by wealthy ownership

Noticeable restructuring of the media ecosystem, rise of new outlets

Rapid growth of media alts, e.g. social media + current events podcasts

Further declining trust (polled)

The reason this will cost credibility is the turnaround time. When a prediction fails fast, it looks like poor judgment or incompetence. When it fails slowly, people have a hard time remembering what the info environment was at the time it was made & have largely stopped caring

When news media make claims that are actually predictions but are presented as facts, they can shift rapidly between the two. When the prediction succeeds, it's "we reported the facts first." When it fails, it's "this was a reasonable prediction to make given what we knew then." https://t.co/iHSgvO78Eg

text: @ESYudkowsky One of the most egregious things I've heard from journo world, straight from the subject: they recorded an interview for over an hour; the journalist took a sentence fragment from the first half and another from the second half, then strung them together to get the money quote.

@Jason I'd estimate 0.5-1% CFR where hospital systems aren't overwhelmed (to the point of triage to palliative) & 2+% where they are

Risk factors aren't evenly distributed. 10.9% of Americans are diabetic. Last data I saw: 1/3 of ICU cases diabetic. We're not going to look like S Korea

@Jason This disease breaks brains. High R0 + a 1-2 week lag from infection to symptoms & a 3-4 week lag from infection to death means the current state of the system is completely opaque w/o ubiquitous testing

That said, long-term lockdown isn't risk averse, it's insane, we need a plan

text: Love all the infographics, but I wish y'all would use data at the city/county level and aggregate surrounding areas into sensible clusters. Science types probably hate eyeballing it or choosing arbitrary exclusion criteria, but guys, it's dumb to use the lines humans draw on maps
If you try to mash the Seattle, SF, LA, NOLA, Chicago, Detroit & NYC outbreaks into a single data row called "United States," you're going to lose a lot of clarity on our situation
@alt_kia @KelseyTuoc @geekethics @sonyasupposedly (In all of these tweets I'm discussing the study context, which wasn't concerned with patient mask-wearing)

@KelseyTuoc @geekethics @sonyasupposedly Full mouth coverage and nose coverage (N95) with no eye/skin protection might show efficacy for a while, but I'd anticipate that constant exposure will catch up to you eventually — again, why it's important for all these things to be held constant, but esp. duration & infectivity

@KelseyTuoc @geekethics @sonyasupposedly There's also the issue of other PPE; if the air is constantly being resaturated with droplets and/or particles and you're basically hot-boxing that to treat a patient, anything short of full lab hazmat is going to put you in serious trouble

text: @Hemol33 Fair, patent trolling is/was egregious. The big difference is that everyone agrees that it's a problem, it's not embedded in the culture

Software was largely able to jump the fence because regulators couldn't pretend to understand it and it's usually much easier to build secretly and release strategically; it's also harder to make the case that some hypothetical moron would choke on it or set themselves on fire

I think we're going to learn the hard way that widespread rent-seeking is only annoying during sustained growth — devastating in a crisis.

Nobody can technically stop you from folding up a handkerchief and wearing it, but get much more crafty than that & you better get a lawyer https://t.co/kmN585fjJl

text: When people insist that you need an N95 respirator with an absolutely perfect seal on the face in order for mask-wearing to be any use at all, I wonder how they're squaring that with an R0 of 2-4

This is what happens when idea/discourse-space gets commandeered by people who've spent so long playing weird status games over aesthetics that they literally expect the virus to conform to theme https://t.co/TCxNXoECXN

There's a similar problem with trying to get a handle on CFR — if your cases are still growing exponentially, but it takes 3-4 weeks for people to fall mortally ill, a disproportionately large number of new cases will mask the deaths from earlier cohorts

This seems especially likely to throw off your data if you rapidly ramp up testing capacity while the real-world spread still fits an exponential curve, since a much larger % of your cases will be from the last week than from 2 weeks ago
Important for updating on prevalence of "asymptomatic COVID" — many may be asymptomatic when they test positive, but go on to develop symptoms https://t.co/qHDoMjiuit

text: @hollymathnerd When visiting Costa Rica I'd probably measure it again to see if it's the same at the equator
@hollymathnerd FWIW, if I had it I'd measure it

@BonbonFork Not sure if I will publicly — at least, I'm giving myself permission to keep it 100% private while I'm writing it up so that I don't end up subconsciously adjusting my predictions for public consumption

Anyway, I'm sitting down to a clean spreadsheet and making a list of predictions with confidence level, because I think it's time to apply a little personal epistemic hygiene. This firehose of narratives and data and group chat pass-alongs is unreal

So here I am using media anecdotes & messages from people [claiming to be] doctors & friends-of-friends-in-Spain to give context to data that could be misinterpreted a hundred ways. I don't think this is a terrible thing to do, but the fail rate on truth-seeking that way is high

For example, when I look at Italy's CFR by age, how am I to know whether the elderly are dying at such a tremendously higher rate because they're too sick to help, or because they're receiving palliative care while the young get put on ventilators?

There's a lot of speculation, a lot of data that's hard to contextualize, a lot of claims that look sensible enough but are impossible to verify right now. It's probably the case that some of our most basic widespread assumptions turn out to be partially or completely false
